awd_titl_txt: Improving Student Career Readiness through Experiential Learning and Internships
awd_abstract_narration:
The demand for skilled technicians at manufacturing and construction companies in the Los Angeles, California metropolitan area exceeds the capacity of local manufacturing and architecture technology programs. In addition to seeking employees with technical skills, employers are also looking for graduates who have strong employability skills such as teamwork, communication, and problem solving. To increase student enrollment in technology programs at Pierce College and prepare students for successful technical careers, this project will develop a program for students to integrate the skills and knowledge from their coursework with practical applications in a professional setting. The project will include activities that inform and inspire prospective students about careers in manufacturing and architecture technology. By increasing the supply of skilled technicians for the regional workforce, this project will address industry needs and support the regional economy. 

The goal of this project is to establish a recruitment, retention, and internship model to increase enrollment in career and technical education programs. Recruitment activities will include the development of a hands-on summer program and outreach events for high school students in which current students serve as ambassadors. Traditional technician education often neglects the employability skills that are needed for career success. This project will assist students in developing a broader range of career-readiness skills by actively engaging students in experiential learning through service learning projects, developing a new internship program established through partnerships with local employers, and creating workshops that focus on employability skills. These student learning strategies will be disseminated to the technical education community through NSF and Advanced Technological Education Program (ATE) events, and through ATE project centers and the project’s website. This project is designed to improve recruitment, retention, and employment for technical students, providing a pathway to successful technical careers. This project is funded by the Advanced Technological Education program that focuses on the education of technicians for the advanced-technology fields that drive the nation's economy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project, Improving Student Career Readiness through Experiential Learning and Internships, was developed to provide opportunities for career exploration, preparation, and development in engineering, electronics, and architecture technology programs, for the purposes of (1) creating graduates with strong 21st century employability skills, and (2) improving recruitment and retention into the targeted technical programs.

Results:

Through this project, Pierce College strengthened its partnerships with local employers in the areas of engineering, electronics, and architecture, leading to internships and other employment opportunities, as well as opportunities for students to explore careers through field trips and industry speakers. The project team developed an internal career readiness website for students with career development resources including resume and portfolios, 21st century skills, job search, and preparation for technical careers. In addition, the project team developed a non-credit internship support course for students going through an internship in their field of study. This course provides a supportive community under the guidance of a professor, helping to increase the value students gain from these early work experiences. The impact of this course can be expanded, as it is applicable to students undergoing internships and undergraduate research experiences in a range of majors and careers.

Students engaged in experiential learning through collaboratory projects as part of their curriculum. Students in engineering and architecture courses worked on projects for a client, in which they developed tangible solutions to a problem presented by the client. Students gained important employability skills through these projects, including teamwork and problem solving, as well as technical skills in their field of study. 

Pierce College developed and implemented a multi-day summer career exploration experience, Career Exploration Summer Days (CESD), for high school students, with a focus on career pathways in engineering, electronics, and architecture. A total of 80 high school students attended CESD in 2022 and 2023. The high school students connected with Pierce College faculty, staff, and students, as well as professionals working in the targeted fields. Prospective students were exposed to career possibilities in manufacturing and architecture technology through field trips and panels of industry professionals. In addition, students engaged in a career exploration exercise led by the college career center. A hands-on project that incorporated elements of the three targeted career areas and spanned the multi-day experience, exposed students to technical aspects of the professions in an engaging way that also allowed them to express their creativity. 

Impact:

As a result of the project, the college faculty in the targeted disciplines and the career center are working closely to help students with career development and internship and job placement. In addition, the faculty have adopted the practices of engaging with local employers and with local high schools, leading to an increase in these mutually beneficial partnerships. This has led to high school students taking more college courses in the targeted technical fields, course articulation and dual enrollment discussions and offerings, employees at local companies taking technical courses to upskill, and job placement for students in their fields of study.


Last Modified: 06/26/2024
Modified by: Elizabeth P Cheung
